title: Australia’s competition watchdog sues Google for mishandling Android users’ location data
text:
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) said Google did not properly disclose that users must turn two separate settings off to stop the collection and use of their location data, and did not adequately inform users about how that data would be used. A Google spokesperson said the firm is reviewing the allegations and engaging with the ACCC. (The Logic)

Talking point: This isn’t the first time Google has come under fire for this particular Android issue—in August 2018, following an Associated Press investigation, the firm changed its privacy policy to reflect the two-settings requirement. The Australian regulator is suing Google for its policies before that change, and for what it called an ongoing failure to adequately inform users about how it uses their data. This is the latest in a series of global regulatory actions against tech giants’ data practices, and the first major lawsuit by the Australian watchdog following the July release of its Digital Platforms Inquiry report. The watchdog can impose a fine on a company in three ways: AU$10 million; triple the benefit it received from the wrongdoing; or 10 per cent of a company’s annual turnover in Australia. Google made US$136.22 billion in global revenue last year.
